desc.size: Small to medium-sized tree, 12 - 15 m tall. Crown narrow.

part.partText: reddish brown, densely downy, becoming smooth.
reddish brown, to 2.5 cm long, egg-shaped, pointed, hairy.

alternate, stipules prominent and kidney-shaped, dull green above, paler beneath, 6 - 15 cm long, 2.5 - 3.7 cm wide, lanceolate, base tapering, tip pointed, margins finely toothed, thick, firm, hairy at first, becoming smooth.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in woolly, cylindrical catkins on short, leafy stalks; female catkins greenish, slightly longer than males; male catkins 2 - 5 cm long, scales dark brown, stamens 2, anthers yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; stalked, brown, 7 - 9 mm long, flask-shaped; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix eriocephala is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having finely toothed leaves that are green and hairless on both sides. Leaf margins are flat, not revolute (down-curved). Salix lucida is much smaller and has shiny leaves; S. nigra has narrower leaves; S. pentandra is a smaller tree with elliptical to egg-shaped leaves.

speciesPage.flowering: Early April to mid-May, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Frequent in a wide range of moist to wet habitats. It is common in calcareous sites. Other habitats include second-growth woods, river banks, ditches, and along railroads.

notes.comments: The taxonomy of Salix eriocephala is very complicated. For further discussion consult Argus (1980). Its wood has been used for fence posts, and it is planted as an ornamental.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Eriocephala means woolly-headed.
